Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Protecting and Advancing Water-Energy-Environment and Sustainability (PAWES)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the US becomes a leading producer of hydrocarbons in the world, sustainable practices are needed to leverage this new energy frontier while safeguarding against predicted water scarcity and drought. The proposed Engineering Research Center (ERC) will focus on the challenges related to hydrocarbon production. The Center will specifically address increase in water demand and wastewater sustainability as it relates to stakeholder concerns in rural and tribal communities. The planning grant aims to design the transformative systems approach needed to emphasize solutions that address social and environmental issues. The focus area is driven by the energy industry, which is responsible for up to 15% of total water withdraws worldwide. The planning grant will also bring together experts in the fields of engineering, microbiology, chemistry, environmental policy, economics, and community engagement. This team will develop an economically feasible approach, sustainable energy practices and policy, and revitalized rural communities. It will plan for an engineering system that integrates community perspectives into research, decision-making, and training with social justice, public perspectives, and multi-objective decision-making. The proposed Center will be led by the University of Tennessee with partners at Juniata College, Colorado State University, and Tennessee State University.

The proposed ERC tackles important, complex, and socially-relevant topics such as water scarcity, energy security, and rural and tribal community development. The Center will target the "moonshot" initiative of treating hyper-saline O&G wastewater for industrial uses at $1/barrel. The major impact of this planning grant is to enable the effective evidence-based discussions between interdisciplinary leaders and stakeholders needed to achieve this bold target. Their input will be used to develop a sequence of wastewater management treatments designed to maximize recovery of O&G wastewater for reuse. Implications on water conservation, energy security, and rural and tribal workforce development will help country-wide society. For the proposed wastewater treatment protocols to be successful, basic research in microbiology, microbial ecology, environmental engineering, chemistry, and material science aided by advanced computational models will be needed. The planning process will be used to build effective and active networks, strengthen ongoing research efforts, inform and empower Appalachian and Tribal communities. In addition, the planning grant will be used to establish an integrated approach to engineering education that will teach students about community engagement, policy development, and science communications. These findings could be applied to other types of industrial and agricultural waste, expanding the Center's positive impact to other aspects of the US water supply system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: Award Number: 1936936

Dr. Terry Hazen was awarded a Planning Grant from the National Sciences Foundation to develop a proposal for an Engineering Research Center at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville.  An assembled team of 20+ stakeholders comprised the team supporting the Engineering Research Center for Protecting and Advancing Water-Energy-Environment and Sustainability (PAWES). The vision of the PAWES program is to develop real-time (bio)sensors to track contaminants and pathogens in sewage, rivers, and other sources of water. The sensors upload data to a centralized national (and potentially, global) server, where researchers, health departments, emergency responders, and decision makers can use the latest in machine learning (ML) technology and artificial intelligence (AI) to track community conditions in real time in order to mitigate the terrible impact of water contaminants on public health including heavy metals, drugs, and emerging infectious agents, like SARS CoV-2. The efforts over a one year period were great, the team was able to share goals and objectives of the ERC with the community though the development of the https://pawes.utk.edu/ website and infomercial, valuable connections were established with underrepresented stakeholders and the team received training to implement a science-based process for collaborative strategic action.

 

For stakeholder engagement, underrepresented communities were engaged through a variety of projects. Students in the Appalachian Teaching Project, which emphasizes rural water, wastewater, and public health infrastructure, were engaged in a research project led by team members that resulted in presentation to the Appalachian Regional Commission to help inform regional policies and decision making. At UTK, students in the Civil and Environmental Engineering Department worked on novel technology with team members to develop enhanced wastewater sampling devices. The result is a pending patent disclosure and a functional prototype. The PAWES team employed NISER for an evaluation of several underrepresented communities to understand community thoughts on education, policies, procedures, and getting community input to help engage communities in the future vision and mission of PAWES in a culturally responsive and responsible way.

 

A new agile approach to team dynamics was taught and practiced in a Strategic DoingTM workshop (https://strategicdoing.net/) designed to build team interconnectivity which is crucial for a large multidisciplinary program emphasizing a convergent approach to tackling engineering challenges.

The workshop emphasized leadership skills to facilitate productive and meaningful communications and to ensure ideas are put into actions that move the project forward. This agile approach made room for the rethinking of the ERC goal to make it more relevant to our current times and future direction. The team is currently working on a pilot program linking the campus and community COVID-19 cases with social behavior, and assessing the community understanding of public health safety though a related survey. The results of this effort will be presented in a peer-reviewed journal and policy to inform the UTK administration.
